citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
During inspection, an adult female sable coated guinea pig was found with a severe skin condition that had not been
identified or treated by the facility prior to inspection. There was significant fur loss over most of its body and the skin was
thickened and flaking. Clear signs of itchiness and inflammation were further evident in that large patches of skin were
pink and scabs were present on the abdomen. When questioned, the licensee reported that they were not aware of this
animal’s condition and thus the attending veterinarian had not been notified.
Animals with medical conditions including skin problems may suffer from pain, discomfort, infection, and stress. Daily
observations of animals to identify medical problems is essential for animal health and welfare. Correct by ensuring daily
observation of animals to identify physical, medical, or behavioral problems. Ensure that all findings are communicated in
a timely manner to the attending veterinarian so that they can examine animals and ensure that appropriate treatment is
provided as required by section 2.40(b)(2).
Correct by April 29th, 2023.

There are no acquisition records for any adult or juvenile guinea pig bred at the facility. Disposition records exist for those
that have been sold, however there is no current documentation of disposition other than sale, including by natural death
or euthanasia.
Animal acquisitions including by births, and dispositions including by death, must be recorded to maintain an accurate
animal count. Correct by maintaining complete and accurate records of purchase, acquisition, sale or disposal of animals
in accordance with section 2.75(b)(1) of the Animal Welfare Act.
Correct by May 1, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
During inspection, an adult female sable coated guinea pig was found with a severe skin condition that had not been 
identified or treated by the facility prior to inspection. There was significant fur loss over most of its body and the skin was 
thickened and flaking. Clear signs of itchiness and inflammation were further evident in that large patches of skin were 
pink and scabs were present on the abdomen. When questioned, the licensee reported that they were not aware of this 
animal’s condition and thus the attending veterinarian had not been notified. 
 
Animals with medical conditions including skin problems may suffer from pain, discomfort, infection, and stress. Daily 
observations of animals to identify medical problems is essential for animal health and welfare. Correct by ensuring daily 
observation of animals to identify physical, medical, or behavioral problems. Ensure that all findings are communicated in 
a timely manner to the attending veterinarian so that they can examine animals and ensure that appropriate treatment is 
provided as required by section 2.40(b)(2). 
 
Correct by April 29th, 2023. 
2.75(b)(1)

Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
There are no acquisition records for any adult or juvenile guinea pig bred at the facility. Disposition records exist for those 
that have been sold, however there is no current documentation of disposition other than sale, including by natural death 
or euthanasia. 
 
Animal acquisitions including by births, and dispositions including by death, must be recorded to maintain an accurate 
animal count. Correct by maintaining complete and accurate records of purchase, acquisition, sale or disposal of animals 
in accordance with section 2.75(b)(1) of the Animal Welfare Act. 
 
Correct by May 1, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
